STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 20, 2025
Hope Elizabeth Mulder James
Samaritas-West
2080 Union Ave SE STE A, Suite A
Grand Rapids, MI, 49507-3247
Re: License #: CB410201266
SI #: 2025SIC0000237
Dear Ms. James:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000237
Special Investigation Intake Date: December 23, 2024
License #: CB410201266
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas
Licensee Designee: Rachel Ahna Sykes
Chief Administrator: Hope Elizabeth Mulder James
Agency Name: SAMARITAS - WEST
Agency Address: 2080 UNION AVE SE STE A
Suite A
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49507-3247
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/22/2026

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff qualification, volunteer, contractors on central registry.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
Description and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member did not confiscate a vape from a youth when she
was told about it. This staff member has also vaped in front of the
youths on more than one occasion.
Investigation Interviews
Case Manager, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C
On 12/23/2024 I spoke with Case Manager and interviewed Youth
A, Youth B and Youth C with MDHHS (Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services) Worker who was onsite, and I was
available via a Face-time call. I also interviewed Case Manager
by telephone on 12/23/2024.
Case Manager reported a concern about Staff 1 came up while
she was on vacation on 12/10/2024 and her supervisor,
Independent Living Plus Supervisor (ILPS) brought the matter to
her attention on or about 12/16/2024. She reported there had
apparently been a meeting between Staff 2 and Staff 3 with ILPS
over concerns related to Staff 1. Case Manager did not indicate a
date for that meeting. She reported being informed that during
that meeting an issue of Staff 1 not taking vapes from the youths,
and Staff 1 possibly vaping with the girls was brought up by Staff 2
and Staff 3. She reported youths are prohibited from smoking
2

cigarettes, having vapes, or other substances on the property. Nor
are staff to use any substances with the youth. Case Manager
reported the staff are supposed to confiscate the prohibited items,
if they are seen, or reported to be on the property. Staff are to also
inform her and log the discovery of the said object in their log
book.
Case Manager reported their talks with the youths about this
concern had a mixed conclusion as to whether Staff 1 was
smoking/ vaping, or had not taken vapes from youth when Staff 1
may have observed a youth with such an item. She reported
Youth A and Youth D both reported Staff 1 had vaped around or
with youths. Additionally, Staff 1 had seen youths with vapes and
Staff 1 had not taken the items from the youths. She reported
although Youth A and Youth D reported the information as
indicated above for Staff 1, other youths denied that type of
incident had occurred involving Staff 1. Case Manager did not
name those youths. Case Manager said she has never caught
Youth A with any vapes, but Youth A admitted to buying a vape.
Youth A reporting doing so, because she was curious about it.
Case Manager did not know where Youth A or any youth may
have gotten the vapes. Nor did she believe Youth A was actively
vaping. She said Youth A admitted to trying the vape she
purchased, not liking it, and giving the vape to a staff. Case
Manager reported no staff told her about Youth A having a vape.
Nor did a staff log the matter into the home’s communication log
which is required. Case Manager reported Youth A told her Staff 1
was the staff that took the vape.
Case Manager reported on 12/19/2024 Staff 1 was placed on
administrative leave pending an investigation. She reported this is
the second discipline issue for Staff 1 since Staff 1’s 7/3/2024
employment. The first disciplinary action was a written action on
11/21/2024 related to Staff 1 giving her personal phone number to
the girls which is against policy. Case Manager reported with this
current situation, prior to Staff 1 being placed on leave Staff 1
reportedly went to each of the girls and told each of them that
another youth told on her. Case Manager reported that was not
something Staff 1 should have done. She reported after Staff 1 left
the premises, the girls went after each other by arguing, and
saying some youths had snitched on Staff 1. Case Manager
reported a big commotion came due to the girls arguing, and it led
to a physical incident between Youth A and Youth D where the
police had to be called.
3

Youth A admitted to knowing the Independent Living (IL) house
rules, and the law around not vaping, smoking or purchasing such
substances if one is under age 21. As it related to these
allegation, Youth A stated she was not a snitch, and she refused
to talk with MDHHS Worker and myself.
Youth B reported all the girls in the IL house use nicotine vapes
except for Youth A. She said the girls in the house smoke every
day, but they don’t do so around staff, so staff can’t do anything
about it. Youth B reported Staff 1 has never given her or other
youth vapes. She reported Staff 1 has smoked vapes when Staff
1 has transported her and other youth in Staff 1’s car. Youth B
said Staff 1 has smoked every time she has gotten into Staff 1’s
car. She did not report how many times Staff 1 had smoked with
her and or other youth in the car. She reported staff use their
personal cars to transport them at least two times per week; and
Staff 1 had vaped while driving them more than once.
As to whether Staff 1 contributed to the commotion that occurred
with youths that lead to the police being called, Youth B admitted
to being present and that sometime that day she had heard Staff 1
state “I don’t know why she snitched on me”. She said Staff 1 got
snitched on for something Youth A and Youth D did.
Youth C denied seeing any of the youths in the home use
substances, but she admitted to seeing Staff 1 do so. She said
Staff 1 has transported them in Staff 1’s car and on at least two
occasions Staff 1 had smoked a vape. She said Staff 1 did not tell
her not to report it. Staff 1 also never offered her, or any other
youth to her knowledge, a vape.
Independent Living Plus Supervisor (ILPS)
On 1/2/2025 I interviewed ILPS by telephone. ILPS confirmed the
allegations stated in the complaint. She also confirmed information
as reported by Case Manager related to Staff 2 and Staff 3
coming to her with concerns about Staff 1 and this being Staff 1’s
second disciplinary incident. ILPS said Youth A came to her and
reported that Staff 1 had vaped at the house. Youth A also
reported another youth in the home had a vape and Staff 1 did not
take the vape from the youth. Youth A did not tell ILPS the other
youth’s name. ILPS stated given that Case Manager has a better
relationship with Youth A, and the other youths she had Case
Manager to speak with the youths about the matter. The outcome
of those conversations resulted in the allegations reported in the
complaint.
4

Staff 1
On 1/2/2025 I interviewed Staff 1, with MDHHS Worker by way of
a Facetime call, while DHHS Worker was onsite at Staff 1’s home.
Staff 1 reported she had been placed on administrative leave from
her job due to an altercation that happened between youths,
which had started with an argument over her. Staff 1 denied
knowing what that incident was and denied going to the youths
and asking them whether they had snitched on her. She reported
knowing that all the youths in the home use substances. She said
they smoke weed, tobacco, and drink alcohol. She denied
smoking with, or giving any youths vapes, or witnessing any youth
vape. She reported the agency’s policy around drug use for the
youths at the IL home is that they cannot use substances at the
house or on the property. Additionally, that if a staff catches a
youth with a substance they are to take the item from the youth
and report it to the supervisor.
MDHHS Worker advised Staff 1 that this complaint indicated
Youth A had a vape, which Staff 1 did not confiscate. Staff 1
attempted to explain what occurred. She reported during shift on
Sunday (Staff 1 did not clarify the exact date) Youth A was talking
with her in the office. Youth A reported she had been hanging with
other youths who vape, but said she does not smoke weed.
Youth A told her she gave in to peer pressure and bought a vape.
Staff 1 reported she expressed to Youth A that she thought Youth
A did not vape, and asked Youth A why she bought the vape.
Youth A told her she would give the vape away and Staff 1 asked
Youth A to give the vape to her. Staff 1 said Youth A told Case
Manager about the incident when Case Manager came on the
premises. Staff 1 said she removed the vape. Staff 1 did not say
specifically what she did with the vape. She said she did not have
to give it to a supervisor to dispose of it. She said she did not
write the situation up. She was not sure why she did not write it in
the log. She said she just spoke with Case Manager about the
vape at the end of her shift. She subsequently said it was the first
time she had confiscated a vape from a youth, and so she didn’t
know what to do. She said she spoke with Case Manager about
the vape the next day. She admitted there was another incident
where she saw Youth E, with a vape, and she took it. She
reported this incident was after the one with Youth A and she
disposed of the vape and wrote the matter up in the notes.
Staff 1 reported the agency’s policy around staff smoking
cigarettes or using vapes is that staff cannot do so on the
premises or around the youths. Staff 1 denied vaping on the
premises, or with youths, but admitted she has vaped nicotine in
5

her vehicle when youths were in the back seat. This was when
she transported youths to appointments. She reported not
believing the youths could see her vaping in the front seat. She
reported her vaping with a youth in the car had not been a regular
occurrence as it had occurred less than five times.
Staff 2 & Staff 3
On 1/2/2025 during separate telephone calls MDHHS Worker and
I interviewed Staff 2 and Staff 3. Staff 2 has worked for the
agency for two months and Staff 3 has been employed at the
agency since July 2024. Both reported similar information as Case
Manager related the agency’s policy related to substance
possession and use by IL youths. Staff 2 reported staff are to
abide by similar rules of not using substance on the premise and
they cannot consume any drugs/substances with youth. Staff 3
was not sure of the policy governing staff in this area, but
surmised if youths cannot used on the premises, nor should staff.
Staff 2 reported confiscated items like vapes are to be placed in
the staff’s closet and reported to the supervisor. She reported
being aware of Staff 1, their team leader, violating that protocol on
at least one occasion. She reported about a month prior to this
interview she had confiscated a vape (she did not report who
from) and she put the vape in the staff’s closet. She said at some
point that day she spoke with Staff 1 about the vape and Staff 1
told her not to dispose of it. Staff 1 told her Staff 1 would dispose
of the vape. Staff 2 said when she checked on the vape later, it
was gone and there was no note documented about it by Staff 1.
Staff 2 further reported that about two weeks ago Youth A
reported she and Staff 1 had vaped together in Staff 1’s car while
Staff 1 was transporting her. Staff 2 said she did not report
aforementioned incident to Case Manager at the time, because
she knows that at times the girls will embellish things. She said
she had been uncomfortable reporting matter to Staff 1 due to
Staff 1 tendency to be condescending and rude. She recently
brought up Staff 1’s behavior with ILPS and Case Manager.
Staff 3 reported she works the third shift and youths are usually
sleeping when she is on shift. She denied catching any youth with
or using substances. Nor had she witnessed any staff using any
substances with or around a youth. Staff 3 reported an awareness
of two incidents involving vapes and Staff 1. She reported Staff 2
had mentioned to her that Youth A had been hanging with some
youths who smoke, and Youth A had bought a vape. Staff 3 said
Youth A admitted to her she had started vaping. Youth A also told
6

her she really did not like vaping; and she handed the vape over
to Staff 1. Youth A told her she gave the vape to Staff 1 because
Staff 1 vapes. Staff 3 reported Youth A also reported that Staff 1
had purchased vapes for her and Youth F who left the IL home
two months ago.
Staff 4 & Youth D
Staff 4 and Youth D were interviewed by MDHHS Worker and I by
telephone on 1/7/2025 and 1/8/2025 respectively.
Staff 4 reported being an Intern at the IL home since August
2024. She reported information similarly to Staff 3 as it relates to
what staff are to do about youths using or possessing substances,
nicotine vape, etc. and the rule for staff related to them not using
substance on the premises. She denied ever witnessing a staff
smoke or use nicotine vapes in front of youths. Nor had she heard
of any staff doing such. If staff confiscate substances from a
youth, Staff 4 reported the item is to be disposed of off the
property so that the youth cannot get it. She reported Case
Manager has reported disposing of items at a dumpster or gas
station.
Youth D reported living at the IL home for one year. Youth D
confirmed what other youths had reported about youths not being
allowed to use or have drugs (marijuana vapes, cigarettes,
nicotine vapes, etc.) or other paraphernalia or weapons on the
premises. She said if they get caught with any of those items, the
item gets taken by Case Manager, is thrown away, and they get a
consequence. Youth D admitted she had an altercation with
Youth A that resulted in staff calling the police. She said because
of their altercation they are both getting kicked out. She said she
told Youth A that Youth A snitched on Staff 1 and now Staff 1 is
getting fire for vaping and talking about her sex life with youths.
Youth D further admitted she had seen Staff 1 vaping, but it was
not on the agency’s property. She was in the back seat of Staff
1’s car while Staff 1 was transporting them. Youth D did not report
what other youth was in the car with her. She reported it was
clear that they could see Staff 1 vaping from the back seat. She
said it was not a secret what Staff 1 was doing. Staff 1 was not
hiding it. Youth D denied any staff knowing about this matter.
Chief Administrator (CA)
I had contact with CA initially on 12/23/2024 by email about the
allegation. She reported awareness of the concerns because the
agency reported them. Subsequently on 1/9/2025 and 1/10/2025
via email, CA provided some clarifications related the agency’s
7

policy. CA reported staff do sometimes transport youth in their
own vehicles and according to the agency’s policy, smoking would
be prohibited during any time staff are working and clocked in.
Documentation Review:
• The agency’s Search & Prohibited Items Policy which
included illegal drugs, cigarettes, alcohol, legal prescription
drugs not prescribed for the individual and drug
paraphernalia as items prohibited.
• Staff 1’s training record showing her training on various
agency topics.
• The agency’s no smoking policy, which indicated in keeping
with Samaritas’ healthy work environment and complying
with Michigan’s No-Smoke law, smoking is prohibited at all
times in all Samaritas communities, on all Samaritas
property, including Samaritas vehicles and parking lots.
Also, that employees are expected to maintain the agency’s
commitment to a professional image and utilize the
programs and services available to avoid smoking/tobacco
use during the workday and to avoid exposing others to
second hand smoke. Additionally, that if employees choose
to smoke or use tobacco products, smoking must be done
during meal and break time, with supervisory approval.
Analysis Based on interviews, documents reviewed, Staff 1’s own
admission of vaping while transporting youths, and Staff 1 not
reporting when or how she disposed of a vape she confiscated
from a youth Staff 1 did not adhere to agency policies and did not
demonstrate responsible character suitable and able to meet the
needs of children.
Conclusion Violation Established.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
February 25, 2025
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
